author: Frost
text: One of my wishes is that those dark trees,

author: Frost
text: So old and firm they scarcely show the breeze,

author: Frost
text: Were not, as 'twere, the merest mask of gloom,

author: Frost
text: But stretched away unto the edge of doom.

author: Frost
text: I should not be withheld but that some day

author: Frost
text: Into their vastness I should steal away,

author: Frost
text: Fearless of ever finding open land,

author: Frost
text: Or highway where the slow wheel pours the sand.

author: Frost
text: I do not see why I should e'er turn back,

author: Frost
text: Or those should not set forth upon my track

author: Frost
text: To overtake me, who should miss me here

author: Frost
text: And long to know if still I held them dear.

author: Frost
text: They would not find me changed from him they knew

author: Frost
text: Only more sure of all I thought was true.

author: Frost
text: I had withdrawn in forest, and my song

author: Frost
text: Was swallowed up in leaves that blew alway,

author: Frost
text: And to the forest edge you came one day

author: Frost
text: (This was my dream) and looked and pondered long,

author: Frost
text: But did not enter, though the wish was strong:

author: Frost
text: You shook your pensive head as who should say,

author: Frost
text: 'I dare nottoo far in his footsteps stray

author: Frost
text: He must seek me would he undo the wrong.'

author: Frost
text: Not far, but near, I stood and saw it all

author: Frost
text: Behind low boughs the trees let down outside;

author: Frost
text: And the sweet pang it cost me not to call

author: Frost
text: And tell you that I saw does still abide,

author: Frost
text: But 'tis not true that thus I dwelt aloof,

author: Frost
text: For the wood wakes, and you are here for proof.

author: Frost
text: If tired of trees I seek again mankind,

author: Frost
text: Well I know where to hie mein the dawn,

author: Frost
text: To a slope where the cattle keep the lawn.

author: Frost
text: There amid lolling juniper reclined,

author: Frost
text: Myself unseen, I see in white defined

author: Frost
text: Far off the homes of men, and farther still,

author: Frost
text: The graves of men on an opposing hill,

author: Frost
text: Living or dead, whichever are to mind.

author: Frost
text: And if by noon I have too much of these,

author: Frost
text: I have but to turn on my arm, and lo,

author: Frost
text: The sunburned hillside sets my face aglow,

author: Frost
text: My breathing shakes the bluet like a breeze,

author: Frost
text: I smell the earth, I smell the bruis√®d plant,

author: Frost
text: I look into the crater of the ant.

author: Frost
text: There was never a sound beside the wood but one,

author: Frost
text: And that was my long scythe whispering to the ground.

author: Frost
text: What was it it whispered? I knew not well myself;

author: Frost
text: Perhaps it was something about the heat of the sun,

author: Frost
text: Something, perhaps, about the lack of sound

author: Frost
text: And that was why it whispered and did not speak.

author: Frost
text: It was no dream of the gift of idle hours,

author: Frost
text: Or easy gold at the hand of fay or elf:

author: Frost
text: Anything more than the truth would have seemed too weak

author: Frost
text: To the earnest love that laid the swale in rows,

author: Frost
text: Not without feeblepointed spikes of flowers

author: Frost
text: (Pale orchises), and scared a bright green snake.

author: Frost
text: The fact is the sweetest dream that labor knows.

author: Frost
text: My long scythe whispered and left the hay to make.

author: Frost
text: There is a singer everyone has heard,

author: Frost
text: Loud, a midsummer and a midwood bird,

author: Frost
text: Who makes the solid tree trunks sound again.

author: Frost
text: He says that leaves are old and that for flowers

author: Frost
text: Midsummer is to spring as one to ten.

author: Frost
text: He says the early petalfall is past

author: Frost
text: When pear and cherry bloom went down in the showers

author: Frost
text: On sunny days a moment overcast;

author: Frost
text: And comes that other fall we name the fall.

author: Frost
text: He says the highway dust is over all.

author: Frost
text: The bird would cease and be as other birds

author: Frost
text: But that he knows in singing not to sing.

author: Frost
text: The question that he frames in all but words

author: Frost
text: Is what to make of a diminished thing.

author: Frost
text: The battle rent a cobweb diamondstrung

author: Frost
text: And cut a flower beside a ground bird's nest

author: Frost
text: Before it strained a single human breast.

author: Frost
text: The stricken flower bent double and so hung.

author: Frost
text: And still the bird revisited her young.

author: Frost
text: A butterfly its fall had dispossessed

author: Frost
text: A moment sought in air his flower of rest,

author: Frost
text: Then lightly stooped to it and fluttering clung.

author: Frost
text: On the bare upland pasture there had spread

author: Frost
text: O'ernight 'twixt mullein stalks a wheel of thread

author: Frost
text: And straining cables wet with silver dew.

author: Frost
text: A sudden passing bullet shook it dry.

author: Frost
text: The indwelling spider ran to greet the fly,

author: Frost
text: But finding nothing, sullenly withdrew.
